messageBody:
Hello all,

I have revised my original mapping proposal.
My goals for the mapping remain as before:
- the mapping should be easy to learn/remember as well as easy and
efficient to type,
- also it should be easy to read when the required quikscript font
is missing and the text is subsequently displayed in a

default english font.


# The mapping is:

pea <-> p

bay <-> y

tea <-> t

day <-> d

key <-> k

gay <-> g

thaw <-> T

they <-> D

fee <-> f

vie <-> v

see <-> s

zoo <-> z

she <-> S

j'ai <-> Z

cheer <-> C

jay <-> j

ye <-> y

way <-> w

he <-> h

why <-> P

ing <-> N

may <-> m

no <-> n

low <-> l

roe <-> r

it <-> i

eat <-> E

et <-> e

eight <-> A

at <-> a

eye <-> I

ah <-> R

awe -> Q : alternative- ö

ox <-> o

oy <-> Y

utter -> u : alternatives- à è ì ò

out <-> W

owe <-> O

foot <-> V

ooze <-> U

loch <-> K

llan <-> L

Excite <-> x

Exam <-> X

null (ie: no character) -> H Á É Í Ó Ú Ý

Note 1 : 'H Á É Í Ó Ú Ý' all map to the null character. I assume it
possible to map to nothing (is this possible?). Use these if you
wish to make a word appear similar to the TO spelling to improve
english font readability.
Note 2 : For 'utter' there are multiple mappings. The primary one to
use is 'u' but if you need to improve the english font readability
you may use either 'à è ì ò'.
Note 3 : For 'awe' there is an alternate mapping. The primary one to
use is 'Q' but use 'ö' when wishing to improve english font
readability.



# Differences between this and my previous mapping :

--- Differences between letters previously assigned ---

- why <-> P : instead of W :
Reason : To accomodate the new 'out' phoneme mapping below. Since
the 'why' phoneme is not used by most people it shouldn't bother
most that it is mapped to a very illogical key.

- out <-> W : instead of H :
Reason: Forms part of the TO letter combination 'OW'- if map 'Ó'
to 'null' then can use 'ÓW' for this phoneme when writing to
maximise english font readability. (eg: _how_ -> hÓW). Also in my
very non-representative and statistically irrelevant survey of three
people, all surveyees chose this letter.

- oy <-> Y : instead of q :
Reason: Forms part of the TO letter combination 'OY' - if map 'Ó'
to 'null' then can use 'ÓY' for this phoneme when writing to
maximise english font readability. (eg: _boy_ -> bÓY).

- null -> É : instead of È :
Reason : for consistency in the use of diacritics regarding
the 'utter' and 'null' mappings. ie: all alternate 'utter' keys use
the grave diacritic, while the 'null' keys (except 'H') all use the
acute diacritic.

- null -> H :
Reason: increases english font readability if combined with 'T', 'S'
and 'C' (when desired). eg: _think_ -> THiNk , _ship_ -> SHip and
_chip_ -> CHip.


--- Additional assignments ---

- loch <-> K :
Reason: same as other proposals

- llan <-> L :
Reason: same as other proposals

- Excite <-> X :
Reason: same as half of other proposals. Chose upper case to stay
consistent with the common theme of upper case letters saying their
own name. Chose this even though 'excite' is more frequent in use
than 'exam'. In this case both letters are so infrequent that the
possible shift key stroke saving would hardly amount to anything.

- Exam <-> x :
Reason: same as half of other proposals, see 'excite' above.

- Noon <-> M :
Reason: same as some of the other proposals, have run out of logical
assignments.

- Up <-> G :
Reason: arbitrary mapping, have run out of logical assignemts

- naming dot <-> ` :
Reason: same as other proposals.

- left bracket <-> ( :
Reason: same as other proposals.

- right bracket <-> ) :
Reason: same as other proposals.

- more utter mappings 'à è ì ò' :
Reason : to improve english font readability as required. eg: use
one of these to replace a TO vowel glyph that makes a shwa (/@/)
sound in a word (using an australian accent)- _abet_ -> àbet ,
_begin_ -> bègiN , _rigid_ -> rijìd , _occur_ -> òkur

- more null mappings 'Á É Í Ó Ú Ý' :
Reason to improve english font readability as required. eg: combine
the acute marked null characters with the mapped capital letter
vowels/diphthongs- _see_ -> sEÉ , _seat_ -> sEÁt , _here_ -> hErÉ ,
_main_ -> mAÍn , _day_ -> dAÝ , _mate_ -> mAtÉ , kite -> kItÉ ,
_boat_ -> bOÁt , _note_ -> nOtÉ , _lute_ -> lUtÉ , _cow_ -> cÓW ,
_boy_ -> bÓY


# A memory guide/summary of explanation of mapping :

-all lower case consonant keys that are used in the mapping say the
usual sound that everyday people are familiar with

already. eg: 'b' maps to 'bay', 'j' to 'jay', 'y' to 'ye', etc.

-a mapped upper case consonant key indicates that it does not say
the usual sound. The upper case constant mappings are

similar to other key mapping proposals.

-all lower case vowel keys say the usual short vowel sounds: ie: 'a
e i o u' map to the vowel sounds in the words _bat_, _bet_, _bit_,
_bot_ (british english accent - not merged american) and _but_
respectively.

-all upper case vowels say their own name: ie: 'A E I O U' map to
the vowel sounds in the words _say_, _see_, _sigh_, _sew_, _sue_
(well 'U' sort of says its name)

-upper case 'R' says its own name. ie: 'R' maps to the vowel sound
in _car_

-upper case 'W' and 'Y' map to the vowel sounds in the words _cow_
and _coy_

-upper case 'Q' maps to the vowel sound in the word _core_. ('Q'
sort of looks like an 'o')

-upper case 'V' maps to the vowel sound in the word _cook_. (just
have to learn this one)



# Comments on this revision :

- the mapping is now logically split between lower and upper case.
All lower case sound/key mappings are commonly experienced in
everyday english. Whereas upper case sound/key combinations may not
be common nor feel as logical.

- there are now two lower case keys that are not mapped, 'c'
and 'q'. These keys could be used in a quikscripters personal
keyboard mapping as an alternative to two of the mapped upper case
keys. Doing this eliminates some shift key presses.

- the lower case keys map to the most of the most frequently used
letters. Approximately 85% of text only requires lower case key
strokes (according to the quikscript letter frequency chart in the
files/resources folder). If you personally map 'c' and 'q' to
the 'eight' and 'they' letters then this increases to approx 90%,
ie: only 10% of letters typed in normal text require a shift key
press.

- there are now more 'null' and 'utter' mappings compared to the
original proposal. Although these extra mappings can be used to
further improve english font readability, I feel that the principle
that a mapping should minimise null and multiple mappings has much
merit. I'm very open to dicussion about the reducing the number of
these extra mappings.



# Reasons for me wanting to increase english font readability:

- 1. For use when writing for the general public and not
specifically for quikscripters. This offers a way to improve
quikscript awareness. Eg: a web page that is written in quikscript
will still be readable (with effort) by non-quikscripters, ideally
such a web page would provide a link to explain why the writing is
strange and offer a chance for the readers to learn more about
quikscript. (This is my personal primary motivation as it is a
situation that I'm currently facing with one of my websites that is
written in quikscript. The website is about a free GPL'ed booking
keeping program that I'm coding. I'm thinking about writing all the
dialog and help messages within the program in quikscript as well.)

- 2. Even if users are not interested in learning QS per se, by
having them read text which is basically a phonemic mapping
increases their phonemic awareness and lighlights the obsurdity that
traditional english spelling has degenerated to. Realising the
obsurdity of TO is half the battle of spelling reform. (I
personally found that learning the QS alphabet itself to be very
easy. The real challenge I had of writing QS lies in being able to
phonemically sound out words. Many times I would write a word how I
thought it sounded only to find that the dictionary pronounced it
different. At first I would think that the dictionary was wrong,
until I listened very carefully to how the word was normally
pronounced. A major cause of this error was that the traditional
spellings were negatively biasing how I perceived the sounds of
words.)

- 3. People new to QS can use the english font readability to ease
themselves into QS. By first reading text (such as the QS-news
feeds) in an english font they can increase their phonemic
awareness. Then they can gradually introduce new QS letters every
few days by using find/replace to replace the english font with a QS
font for each new letter. (Of course, instead of doing this font
replacement manually, some super-techie quickscripter would be able
to write a small program that downloads the news-feed and does this
automatically for them :) ). This would result in a progressive
tutorial approach like my Alice-in-Wonderland tutes, except they
explicitly control how fast and in which order they progress to each
new letter.



Merry Christmas All
Peter
